content: # Non-Condensing Boiler Components: Fault Finding Guide

This comprehensive guide covers diagnostic procedures for components specific to non-condensing boilers, including pilot assemblies, thermocouples, gas valves, and other traditional components not typically found in modern condensing systems.
- **Permanent Pilot**: Small flame that stays lit continuously
- **Intermittent Pilot**: Lights only when heat is called for
- **Direct Spark Ignition**: No pilot, uses spark to light main burner
- **Gas Valve**: Controls gas flow to burners
- **Thermocouple/Thermopile**: Flame proving device for standing pilot
- **Pilot Gas Line**: Supplies gas to pilot burner
- **Primary Heat Exchanger**: Typically cast iron or copper
- **Heat Exchanger Baffles**: Direct flue gas flow
- **Draft Hood**: Dilutes and directs flue gases
- **Fan/Draft Inducer**: Forces combustion products out (fan-assisted models)
- **Fan Pressure Switch**: Ensures proper venting (fan-assisted models)
## PART 2: PILOT ASSEMBLY AND IGNITION SYSTEM FAULTS
- Pilot lights but goes out when button released
- Pilot lights but main burner won't ignite
- Correct flame: Strong, blue, engulfs thermocouple tip
- Incorrect flame: Yellow, weak, or not touching thermocouple
- Equipment needed: Multimeter with millivolt setting
1. Light pilot and keep it lit for 2-3 minutes
2. Measure millivolt output at gas valve connection
4. Low reading (<20mV): Faulty thermocouple or poor positioning
- Check pilot gas line for blockages
- Confirm gas pressure at test point (typically 8-10 mbar)
- Bleed air from gas line if newly installed/serviced
- Hold pilot button longer (1-2 minutes) to purge air
- Solution: Clean pilot assembly with soft brush and compressed air
- Symptoms: Pilot goes out when button released
- Cause: Worn thermocouple generating insufficient millivolts
- Solution: Replace thermocouple, ensure proper positioning in flame
- Solution: Carefully adjust pilot tube to direct flame at thermocouple
- Solution: Purge line, check for low points where moisture collects
- Listen for clicking during ignition attempt
- Verify gas reaches pilot during ignition attempt
- Check pilot line and orifice for blockages
- Clean flame rod with fine sandpaper
- Check for cracks in ceramic insulator
- Measure microamp signal during operation (should be >0.7μA)
- Symptoms: No spark, no ignition attempt
- Solution: Clean connections, verify proper grounding
- No gas flow to main burner
- Measure voltage to valve during call for heat
- Standing pilot systems: Verify millivolt power (500-750mV)
- Measure resistance across valve coil terminals
1. Connect manometer to inlet pressure test point
- Listen for audible click when valve should open
- Check for free movement of internal components (when safe)
- Verify gas flow when manually operated (if applicable)
- Symptoms: Reduced gas flow, low flame
- Symptoms: Valve won't open, buzzing sound
- Cause: Burned out coil or partial short
- Symptoms: Poor combustion, yellow flames, sooting
- Cause: Wrongly adjusted or faulty regulator
- Solution: Adjust pressure or replace regulator/valve
### Gas Valve Wiring and Control Problems
- Measure voltage to valve during each stage of operation
- Check for voltage drop in wiring
- Look for heat damage near terminals
- Bypass thermostat to test valve directly
- Check for interference from other controls
- Verify high limit controls are not interrupting
- Solution: Secure all connections, replace damaged terminals
- Symptoms: Valve clicks but won't open fully
- Solution: Correct wiring issues, replace transformer if needed
- Look for external signs of water leakage
- Check for rust or corrosion at joints
- Test CO levels in flue gas
- High CO (>150ppm) may indicate exchanger issues
- Check O₂ and CO₂ levels for proper combustion
- Measure water temperature entering and leaving exchanger
- Low differential indicates scaling or flow problems
- Symptoms: Water leakage, especially during startup/shutdown
- Solution: Replace sections or entire exchanger
- Symptoms: Kettling noise, reduced heat transfer
- Solution: Chemical descaling (if mild), replace if severe
- Symptoms: Small water leaks during operation
- Solution: Clean flue ways, replace baffles
- Calculate flow rate using heat output formula
- Test vent points for trapped air
- Symptoms: Reduced flow, high pressure drop
- Solution: Power flush system, clean waterways
- Solution: Proper bleeding, install automatic air vents
- Cause: Chemical reactions in system water
- Solution: Clean system, treat with inhibitor
- Normal: Blue flames with slight orange tips
- Abnormal: Yellow/orange flames, lifting, or floating
- Check for even distribution across burner
- Test gas pressure at test points
- Inspect air shutters for correct opening
- Adjust to achieve proper flame characteristics
- Inspect for debris in burner ports
- Check for rust flakes or carbon buildup
- Cause: Carbon, rust, debris in ports
- Solution: Clean burner with soft brush, compressed air
- Symptoms: Yellow flames or lifting flames
- Solution: Adjust air shutters, verify gas pressure
- Symptoms: Flames impinging on heat exchanger
- Cause: Physical damage or improper installation
- Solution: Realign burners to manufacturer specifications
- Symptoms: Improper flame size, poor combustion
- Cause: Wrong size or partially blocked orifices
- Solution: Verify correct size, clean or replace
- Burner fails to light despite gas flow
- Burner cycles on and off frequently
- Note any unusual sounds or patterns
- Verify flames spread properly across burner
- Solution: Clean pilot/ignition system, check gas pressure
- Solution: Clean ports, verify proper alignment
- Cause: Oversizing, thermostat issues, airflow problems
- Solution: Address underlying cause, adjust controls
## PART 6: DRAFT AND VENTING SYSTEM DIAGNOSIS
- Boiler cuts out on high limit
1. Insert probe into flue pipe after draft hood
2. Normal reading: -0.01 to -0.02 inches water column
- Hold smoke source near draft hood edges
- Observe if smoke is drawn in or spills out
- Test during cold start and after 5 minutes of operation
- Check for rust, corrosion, or damage
- Solution: Clean flue, check sizing, verify proper installation
- Solution: Reinstall according to manufacturer specifications
- Fan runs but boiler won't fire
- Verify fan starts at correct time in sequence
- Check pressure switch tubing for blockages
- Verify correct routing of pressure tubes
- Symptoms: Fan runs but boiler won't fire
- Cause: Switch contacts worn or diaphragm damaged
- Solution: Replace motor or capacitor as needed
- Solution: Clear blockage, check for proper installation
- Inspect for water damage or corrosion
- Test for continuity in limit circuit
- Verify proper signal voltage from sensors
- Symptoms: Component won't activate despite call
- Solution: Replace board, fix source of moisture
- Procedure: Power off for 30 seconds, restore power
- Note: Persistent issues after reset indicate hardware failure
- Jump out temporarily to test circuit
- Test switch operation at various pressures
- Test proper operation by lowering water level (if possible)
- Solution: Clean or replace low water cutoff
- Feel inlet and outlet pipes for temperature difference
- Listen for smooth operation without cavitation
- Symptoms: Humming but not turning, overheating
- Solution: Free seized rotor or replace pump
- Cause: Air trapped in pump housing
- Solution: Bleed pump, vent system properly
- Solution: Replace pump or rebuild if possible
- Test air pressure when system cold
- Check for water in air chamber
- Verify pressure drops to normal when cool
- Cause: Debris in seat, spring fatigue
- Symptoms: Pressure rises rapidly when heated
- Cause: Ruptured diaphragm, loss of air charge
- Cause: Rapid valve closure, air pockets
- Solution: Install water hammer arrestor, proper venting
| Component | Parameter | Normal Value | Warning Signs |
| Pilot Flame | Appearance | Blue, steady | Yellow, flickering |
| Main Burner | Flame Color | Blue with orange tips | Yellow, floating |
| Gas Valve | Outlet Pressure (NG) | 8-10mbar (typical) | Varies by model |
| Draft | Negative Pressure | -0.01 to -0.02" WC | Positive reading |
| Fan | Current Draw | See rating plate | >10% of rating |
| Pump | Noise Level | Low hum | Grinding, cavitation |
| System | Working Pressure | 1-1.5 bar cold | <0.5 bar or >2.5 bar |
| Valve Type | Component | Normal Resistance | Notes |
| Honeywell VR8200 | Main Coil | 2-3 kΩ | Values vary by model |
| SIT Nova | Main Coil | 1.6-2.2 kΩ | Check manufacturer specs |
| White Rodgers | Main Coil | 1.8-2.5 kΩ | Higher when cold |
- Use proper tools to avoid damage
- Never use a flame to check for leaks
- Pay special attention to recently disturbed fittings
- Always check CO levels after service
- Follow local regulations for ventilation requirements
- Know when to refer to specialists
